column13: Description
Cubic form vase with rounded edges clear glazed with beige glaze around narrow neck and base impressed criss cross pattern on two sides.

This stoneware plate dating from around 1950 is decorated in green glaze, with black enamelled and incised decoration. It was designed and made by Ray Marshall at the Milland Pottery, Hampshire. The plate is used to illustrate the history of modern design.
Bulbous stoneware vase applied with a asymmetrical loops of clay finished with a glazed green and brown.
A brooch, moulded in high relief as an oval ivory face. Enamelled with a striped gilt hat. Created by Cicada.
A small brooch, moulded into a high relief as an oval face, enamelled with a black hat and net.
A small brooch, moulded into a high relief as an ivory coloured face with a sloth hat and hair.
A necklace consisting of alternating black circles with white and red designs and black squares with white designs.
A pair of earrings with a black and white circular design. Created by Cicada.

column13: A pair of earrings with a black and white circular design. Created by Cicada.A pair of earrings with a black and white circular design. Created by Cicada.
A necklace consisting of eleven semi circle beads, some plain green and purple floral material.
A necklace with Clarice Cliff landscape inscribed on seven semicircular beads and ivory coloured spacers.
A transparent brooch in parrot design, decorated with metallic paint and enamel.
A transparent brooch in parrot design, decorated with metallic paint and enamel.
This brooch, in the form of a butterfly, is cast in polyester resin and enamelled. It was made by Cicada, a Brighton based jewellery company, in the 1970s or 1980s.

A dress clip with stylised insect design. It was made by Cicada, a Brighton based jewellery company, in the 1970s or 1980s.
This silver bread basket was designed and made by Rebecca de Quin in 1999. It is used by the museum to illustrate the history of twentieth century design.

This silver fish slice was designed and made by Frances Julie Whitelaw in 1998. It has an almond-shaped flat slice pierced with 6 eyelets and curved hollow rib-cage handle. The fish slice is used by the museum to illustrate the history of twentieth century design.

column13: Porcelain cup with tie-on label and porcelain mat, called Marriage. Cup in Victorian style, unglazed, partially patterned and stained brown and damaged, bears paper label printed with image of a couple. Created to look old. Mat moulded as a woven textile.

column5: Anna Dickinson; Neil Wilkin; Mehmet Kuzu
column13: This glass vase called Tall Brown Vase, is made from dark brown glass, with cut vertical flutes and an electroformed copper collar. It was designed and made by Anna Dickinson in 1998. The vase exemplifies Anna's vision for a monumental piece of blown glass, simply but dramatically decorated. An exceptionally large piece, its shape and the deep vertical grooves carved in its surface suggest the form and gentle entasis of a column supporting the entablature of a classical temple.  It is, as Dan Klein has said of her work, 'a miniature monument'.  The electroformed copper collar around the rim of the vase, subtly patinated in blue, suggests both a find made by a marine archaeologist and a slightly cloudy view of the heavens.  Anna Dickinson's work is steeped in tradition but the subtle attenuation of the proportions of this vase and the restraint apparent in its decoration make it very much a work of today.The vase is used by the museum to illustrate the history of modern design.
This figure group, entitled Bud and Barkage, is hand-built in earthstone clay and decorated with coloured slips, glazes and enamels. It was made by Carole Windham in 2000.
This vase, entitled Difficult Background, is hand-built in earthenware, incised, enamelled and lustre-decorated. It was made by Grayson Perry in 2001.

This high-fired, earthenware vase with reduced mottled pink glaze over pale blue was designed and made by Reginald Wells at the Coldrum Pottery around 1910. The vase is used to illustrate the history of twentieth century design.
Very large, very thinly potted shallow earthenware dish glaze and lustre decorated with abstract, sea-inspired design.
This vase, entitled Sheepfold was hand-built by James Tower in 1980. It is made from tin glazed earthenware.
This large jug, entitled Rucksack Toby, is hand-built in earthenware with coloured enamels. It was made by Richard Slee in 1994.
This stoneware vase, decorated with coloured spirals within clay, was handmade by Lucie Rie in 1975.
